div.l: There is right atte the west syde of ytaile
Downe atte the rote of vesulus the oold
A lusty playne abundaunte of vitaile
Ther many a towne and towr̉er/re thou maist behold
That foundid were of Faders oolde
And many an other delectable sight
And saluceꝭes this noble contrey hight
A Marquis whilom dwellid in that londe
As wer his worthy elders here byfore
And obeysaunte ey redy vnto his honde
Wher al his liges bothe lesse and more
Be louyd and dred thurgh fauour and fortune
Thus in delyte he lyveth and hath doon yore
Bothe of his lordis and eke of his commyne
Ther with he was to speke as of lynage
The gentilist boorne of al lumbardy
A faire ꝑper/parsone strong and yonge of Age
And ful of honour and curtesey
Discrete I nowe his contrey for to gide
Saue in sum thyngꝭes he was to blame
And Wantre was the yonge lordꝭes name
I blame hym thus that he concydered nought
In tyme commyng what myght be tide
But on his luste psent was al his thought
For to hauke and hunte on eủer/rey syde
Welnyght al other cures he lette slyde
And eke he nold that was worst of al
Wedde no wyf for ought that myght befal
Oonly this poyntꝭes his people bar so sor
That Flokmele on a day to hym they went
And oon of theym that wysest was of lore
Or ellis that the lorde wold best assent
That he shulde tel hym what the people ment
Or ellꝭes couche he suche matere
He to the Marquis said as ye shuld here
O noble Marquis your humanite
Assureth vs and yevith vs hardynesse
As oftyn tymys as is of necessite
That we to you may tel our hevynesse
Acceptith you of your gentilnesse
That with pytevous herte we to you playne
And lette not your heires my voyce disdeyne
Al haue I nought to doo in this mattere
More than an other man in this place
Yet for asmuche as ye my lorde so dere
Haue al way shewid me favour and grace
I dare the better aske of you aspace
Of audiens to shewe our request
And ye My lorde to doo right as ye liste
For certꝭes lorde so wel vs liketh you
And al your workys and eủer/re haue doon that we
Ne cowde not our selue deuyse howe
We myght lyve mor in felicite
Save oo thyng lorde yf it your wilbe
That for to be aweddid man yf you liste
That were your peple in soủer/reayne herte rest
Bowyth your nek vndir the blessful yoke
Of soủer/reenyte not of service
Which men clepe spousail or wedlok
And thynkyth lorde a monge your thoughtꝭes wyse
Howe that your days passyn in sundry wyse
For thought we slepe wake ren or ryde
Ay fleith the tyme it wil no man a byde
And though your grene youth flour as yit
In crepith age as stil as any stone
And deth manaceth eủer/rey age and smyte
In euch age for there askapith noon
And also certeyn as we knowe euchone
That we shal dye and vncerteyne we al
Be of that day that dethe shal on vs fal
Acceptith then of vs the trew intent
That eủer/reeủer/re yet refusid your hest
And we wol lorde yf ye wol assent
Chese you a wyf in shorte tyme at the lest
Borne of the gentillest and of the meest
Of al this londe so that it ought seme
Honour to god and you as we can best deme
Delyủer/re vs out of al this bysy drede
And take a wyf for goddis high sake
For yf it so be fel as god forbede
That trough your deth your lynage shulde slake
And that astraunge successour shulde take
Youre herytage woo were vs alyue
Wherfore we pray you hastely to wyue
Ther meke prayers and their petivous chere
Made the Marquis hert haue pite
Ye wil qd he myn ovne peple dere
To that I neủer/re ere thought constrayne me
I me reioyse of my liberte
That seldon tyme is founde in mariage
There I was free I most be in ʆser/siruage
But netheles I se yoᵘur treue intent
And trust vpon your witte and haue aye
Wherfore of my free wil I wil assent
To wede me als sone as eủer/re I may
But ther as ye haue ꝓproferd me to day
To chese me awyf I you relese
That choyse I pray you that ꝓprofer cese
For god it wote that childeren often ben
Vnkil here worthye eldurs hym befor
Bounte cōmmyth al of god not of the sterne
Of whiche they be engendryd and borne
I trust in goddis bounde and therfore
My mariage and myn astate and rest
I hym betake he may doo as he list
Lette me alone inchesyng of my wyf
That charge vpon my bak I wil endur
But I you pray and charge vpon your lyf
What wyf that I take ye me assur
To worship her while that her lyf may dur
In worde and worke bothe here and eủer/rey wher
As she an Emprours doughter were
And forthermore this shal ye sur that ye
Ageyn my choyse shal neủer/re gruch ne stryve
For syn I shal for goon my liber
Atte yoᵘur request as neủer/re nut I pryue
Ther as my hert is sette wil I wyue
And but ye wil assent in suche manere
I pray you spekith no more in this mater
Ful hertely they swar and assent
To al this thyng there said no wight nay
Besekyng hym of grace or that he went
That he wolde graunte hem a certeyn day
Of his spouseil as sone as he may
For yet al wey the peplepeoplepeoplesom what drede
Lest that Marquis wold no wyf wedd
He grauntid hym a day suche as hym list
On which he wolde wedyd sykerly
And said he did al this att their request
And they with humble intent ful buxumly
Knelyng vpon her knees ful reủer/reently
Hym thankyd al and thus they haue anend
Approchid that this weddyng shuld be
And al the paleys put was in aray
Bothe hal and Chamber eche in his degre
Houses of office hangid with grete plente
Ther mais thou se of deynte vitail
That may be founde as far as lastith ytaile
This rioal marquis richely arraied
Lordys and ladies in his company
The which to the feest wer praid
And of his retynue the Bachelary
With many a sowne and sondry melody
Vnto the vilage which I of speke
In this aray the right way he toke
Grysild god woot of this ful innocent
That for her was shapyn al this aray
To fecch water atte a wel is went
And c̄etcomyng as son as eủer/re she may
For wel she lad hard said that ylke aday
That Marquis shuld wedde and yf she myght
She wolde fayne haue seen of that syght
She thought I wil with other maydyns stond
That be my felowes in our dore and see
The marquis and therfor wil I fonde
To haue don at home as sone as it may be
The laboᵘur which that longith vnto me
And than I may at leysour her beholde
Yf she this day vnto the Castel holld
And as she wolde oủer/re the thressholde goon
The Marquis cam and gan her for to cal
And she sette downe her water pot anon
Beside the thressholde of the ox stal
And downe on her knees she gan to fal
And with sad countenᵃnce knelith stil
Til she harde what was the lordys wil
This thought ful Marquis spake to the mayde
Ful soberly and said in this man
Where ys yoᵘur Fader Grisild he said
And she with reủer/reens in humble chere
Answerd lorde he ys al redy here
And she goth in withought lenger lette
And to the Marquis she her Fader fett
He by the hande than toke the poủer/re man
And said thus whan he had hym asyde
Ianicola neyther may ne can
Longer the plesaunce of myn herte hyde
Yf thou fouchsauf what so betyde
Thy doughter wil I take or that I wende
As for my wyf vnto my lyuis ende
Thou louyst me that I wot ʆser/sirtayne
And art my faithful lege man I bore
And al that lykith me I dare wel sayn
It likith the and specially therfore
Tel me that poynt that I haue said before
Yf that thou wylte to that purpose drawe
To take me to thy son in lawe
With this soden case the man astondid was
That rede waxid he and al quakyng
He stode vnneth he said no wordis moo
But oonly thus lorde qd he my wyllyng
Ys as ye wol nargeyns yoᵘur lykyng
I wil no thyng myn owne lorde dere
Right as thou list goủer/rene this mater
Yet wol I qd this Marquis softly
That in thi chamber I nowe and she
Haue a collacioıı̄un and woste thou why
For I wil aske yf it her wil be
To be my wyf and rawle hym after me
And al this shal be doo in thy psens
I wil nought speke oute of thi audiens
And in her Chamb while ye were aboute
Her tretey which ye shal aftyr here
The people cōmme in to the house with oute
And wonderid in how honest man
Ententifly she kepte her Fader dere
But vtterly Grisildys wonder myght
For neủer/re erst ne sawe she suche a sight
No wonder is though were she astonyd
To see soo grete a gest cōmme in that place
She was neủer/re to suche gestes wonte
For which she lokyd with pale face
But shortly this mater for to chase
These ar the wordys that the Marquis said veray
To this begynnyng feithful may
Grisild he said you shal vnderstonde
Yt likith to yoᵘur Fader and to me
That I you wedde and it may so be stond
As I suppose ye wol that it soo be
But these demaundys I aske fyrst qd he
That sen it shal be doon in hasty wyse
Wol you assent or ellꝭes you avyse
I say thus be you redy with goode herte
To al my lust and that ye frely may
And ye neủer/re to gruche neyth ne day
And eke whan I say yee ne say nat nay
Ne by word ne by froward countenᵃnce
Swere this and here I swere oủer/re aliauᵃnce
Wonderyng vpon this worde quakyng for drede
She said lorde in digne and vnworthy
Am I to that honoᵘure that ye me bid
But right as ye wol yoᵘur self so dothe
And herevpon I wil make myn othe
In worke ne in thought you disobey
For to be dede though me were lothe doo dye
This is myn Grysylde myne qd he
And forth he goth with a sobre chere
Out at the dore and aftir cōmme she
And to the people he sayde in this maner
This is my wyf qd he that stondith here
Honoureth her and louyth I you pray
Who so lowith me ther is noo mor to say
And that for nothyng of her oolde gere
She shulde bryng into his house
That wommen shulde dispoyle her ryght there
Of which the ladyes were daungerous
To handle her clothis wherin she was clad
But nethelesse this maydyn bryght of heve
From fote to the hede they clothid haue al newe
Her here they kembyd that lay vndressyd
I sett ful of ouches grete and smale
Vnneth the people knewe her for her fairenesse
Of her aray what shuld I make a tale
Not rudely with her fyngers smale
A Croun on her hed they haue dressyd
Whan she was tᵃnsumtyd in such richesse
This marquis hath her spousid with a ryng
Brought for the same cause and then her sette
Vpon a horse snowe whyte and wel amblyng
And to hys paleis or he lenger lette
With Ioyful people that her ladd and mette
Conueyd her and thus the day ther spend
In reuel til the same gan destende
And shortly forirth this mater to chase
I say to his newe makisessemarkisessemarkisesse
God hath suche fauour send her of his grace
That it not semed no thyng by lyklynesse
That she was bourne and fedde in rudenesse
As in a cote or in a ox stal
But norisshid in an Emprous hal
To eủer/rey wyght waxen she is so dere
And AndAndBut worshipful that folke there she was bore
And from her birthe knewe eủer/rey yere
Wenneth trowed they but durst haue swore
That to Ianycle of which I spake before
She doughter nas as by coniectur
Hem thouth she was an other creatur
For al wey eủer/re vertuous was she
She was encresyd in suche exulens
Of thewes good I sette in high bounte
And so discrete and faier of eloquens
So benigne and digne of reủer/reens
And cowde sothe peoples plece embrace
That euch her louith that lokith in her face
Not oonly of Salutꝭes in the towne
Publisshid was the bounte of her name
But eke ferr̉er/re in many a Regioıı̄un
Yf oon say wele an other saith the same
So spredith of her high bounte the fame
That men and wōmmen as wele yonge as olde
Gothe to Salucꝭes vpon her to beholde
Thus Wauter lowly man ful rially
Weddid with fortunate honesty
IN goddis pece lyuith ful easly
Atte home and grace owtoward Inough hath he
And for that he sawe that vnder lowe degre
Was vertue often hid the people hym helde
A prudent man and that seēmn ful seld
Not oonly this Grisildꝭes thorugh her witte
Cowde al the feete of wyfely humlynesse
But eke whan the cause requirid it
The comyn profitte cowde she redresse
There was no discorde nancoᵘur nor heuynesse
In al that londe that she ne cowde appese
And wysely brynge hem al in hertꝭes ease
Though that her husbonde absent were or nōmon
Yf gentilmēmn or other of her courte
Were wroth she wolde bryng hem atte oon
So ripe and wyse wordꝭes she had
And Iugement of so grete equite
That she from heven sent as men wend
People to saue and eủer/rey wronge to amende
Not longe tyme aftyr that Grysild
Was weddid she a doughter had Ibor
Al had her leủer/re haue borne a knaue child
Glad was the Marquis and his folk therfor
For though a maide childe cōmm al be for
She may vnto knave child atteyne
By lykhod sēmn she is not bareyne
Ther fyl as it fallith tymes moo
Whan this childe had soked but a throwe
This Marquis in herte longith soo
To tempe his wyf her sadnesse for to knowe
That he ne myght oute of his herte throwe
This marvelous desyre his wyf to assay
Now lorge god wote he thought her to affray
He had asayed her Inowe befor
Her for to tempt and alway more and mor
And founde her eủer/re goode what nedith it
Her for to tempe and al way mor and mor
But as for me I say euyl it sitte
Thought sōmm men preyse it for asotil witte
To asay awyf when it is no nede
And put her in anguyssh and in drede
For whiche this Marquis wrought in this maner
He cam a nyght a lone as she lay
With sterne face and troble cher
And said thus Grysild qd he that day
That I toke you oute of yoᵘur poủer/re aray
And put you in this estate in high nobilnesse
Ye haue not for geten as I gesse
I say Grisild this psent dignite
In which I haue put you as I trowe
Makith not yowe for gete ful for to be
That I you take in pour astate ful lowe
For any wele ye mut your self knowe
Take hede of eủer/rey worde that I say
Ther is no wight it herith but we twey
Ye wote yoᵘur self howe ye cam here
Into this house it is not longe a goo
And though ye to me be ryght lefe and der
Vnto my gentles ye be nothyng soo
They sey to hym it is grete shame and woo
For to be subgettis and be in ʆser/sirvage
To the that born art in a smal village
And namely syn thy doughter was bore
These wordys haue they spoke doughtles
But I desyer as I haue doon be fore
To haue my lyf with hem in rest and pese
I may not in this case be rechilles
I mut do with thy doughter for the best
Not as I wil but as my gentillis liste
And yet god wot this is ful lothe to me
But natheles withoute your wittyng
I wol not do but this wil I doo qd he
That ye to me assent in this thyng
Shewe nowe yoᵘur paciens in yoᵘur workyng
That ye me hight and swore in yoᵘur village
The day that made was our mariage
Whan she waswasharde al this she was not amevid
Neyther in worde dede ne countenᵃnce
For as it semed she was not agrevid
She said lorde al lyeth in yoᵘur plesaunce
Mi childe and I with hertly obeysaunce
Been yoᵘurs and ye mowe saue and spil
With yoᵘur owne workith yoᵘur wil
There may no thyng so god my sol saue
Like vnto you that myght displese me
Ne I deyere no thyng to haue
Ne drede for to lese saue oonly ye
This is my herte and ay shal be
No lenght of tyme but deth may this deface
Ne change my corage to any other place
Glad was the marquis for her answeryng
But yet he feyned as he were not soo
Al drery was his chere and his lokyng
When he shulde oute of the Chamb goo
Soon aftyr this afurlong way or too
He pryuely hath told al his intent
Vnto a man and to his wyf he hym sent
Aman sergaunte was this priue man
The which that feithful often founde had
In thyngꝭes grete and eke shuch folke can
Doon execucion of thyngꝭes bad
The lorde knewe wel that he hym louyd and drade
And whan this sergauntsergeauntsergeauntknewe his lordꝭes wil
Vnto the Chamb he stalkith hym ful stil
Madam he said ye must for geve it me
Though I doo noo thyng to which I am constrayned
Ye be so wyse that right wel knowe ye
That lordys hoste may not be feyned
They may be bewayled and compleyned
But men mut nede to her list obey
And so wol I ther nys nomor to sey
This childe I am cōmmaunded for to take
And spake no mor and out the childe he hente
Dispiteously and gan a chere make
Ryght as he wolde haue slayne it or he went
Grisild mut al suffre and al consent
And as a lambe she sittethe meke and stil
And let this cruel ʆser/sirgeaunt haue his wil
Suspecious was the fame of his name
Suspecte his face suspecte word al soo
Suspecte his tyme in which he this be gane
Allas his doughter that she lovid so
She wende he wolde haue slayne it right f tho
But natheles she neither vepte ne sikyd
Confirmed her to that the mquis likid
But at the last speke she be gan
And mekely to the ʆser/sirgeaunte prayd
So as he was a worthy gentilman
That she most kys her child or att it dyed
And in her arme this litil child leyd
With ful sad face and gan the child to blisse
And lullid it and aftir gan it kisse
And thus she said in her benygne voyce
Far wel my childe I shal the neủer/re see
But syn I haue mkyd the with acros
Of goddis son blessid mut he be
Thi soule littil child I hym be take
For this nyght thou shall dy for my sake
I trowe that for a now⁊andabsentnownorce in this case
It had beēmn harde this reuth for to se
Wel myghte a moder then a cryd alas
But nathelesse so sad and so stedfast was she
And to the ʆser/sirgeaunte mekely she said
Haue there a geyne yoᵘur litil yonge maide
Gothe nowe qd she and dothe my lordꝭes hest
But oo thyng wold I pray you of yoᵘur grace
That but my lorde forbade you at the lest
Burieth this litil body in some place
That bestꝭes ne no birdis it to race
But he no worde to the purpose wolde say
But toke the childe and went vpon his way
The ʆser/sirgeaunte cam vnto his lorde a gayne
And of Grisildꝭes wordꝭes and her chere
He tolde hym poynt for poynt short and playn
And hym psentith with his doughter dere
Somwhat the lorde hath ruthe in his manere
But nathelesse his purpose hath he stil
As lordꝭes doon when thay wyl haue their wil
And bad this ʆser/sirgeaunt that he puyly
Shuld this child ful softe wynde and wrap
With al circumstaunce tenderly
And cary it in a cofer or in a cap
But vpon peyn his hed to clap
That no man shuld wit of his intent
Ne whens he cam ne whider he went
But at Boligne it to his suster dere
That thylke tyme of pauyk was countesse
He shuld it take and shewe her this mater
Besekyng her to doo her ʆser/sir besynesse
This child to foster in al gentilnesse
And whose childe that it was he bad her hyde
From eủer/rey wight for ought that myght betyde
This ʆser/sirgeaunt goth and fullfillith this thyng
But to the Marquis nowe tvrne we
For nowe goth he ful ofte ymagenyng
Yf he his wyf ther myght see
Or by her worde ꝑper/parceyve that she
Wer chaungid but he coude her neủer/re fynde
But eủer/re mor lyke sad and kende
As gh glad as humble as besy in ʆser/siruice
And eke in love as she was wont to be
Was she to hym in eủer/rey man wyse
Ne of her doughter not oo worde spak she
None accident for none adủer/resite
Was seyn in her neủer/re her doughter name
Ne nemmed she for ernest ne for game
In this estate ther been passydfoure yere
Or she with childe was as god wolde
A knave child she bare by this Wautere
Ful gracious and feir̉er/re vnto beholde
And whan that folke this the Fader tolde
Not oonly he but al his contrey mery
Was for this childe and god they thankyd and her
Whan it was two yere olde and from the brest
Departyd of his noryce on a day
This marquis caught yet a nother list
To tempte his wyf yet ofter yf he may
Oons nedeles was she temptid in assay
But weddid men knowe no mesure
Whan that they fynde a pacient creature
Wyf qd this Marquis ye haue hard or this
My people sikerly berith our mariage
And namely syn my son born ys
Nowe it is worse then eu in al oủer/re age
The murmoᵘur sleith my herte and my corage
For to myn eris cōmmyth the voyce so smerte
That it welner hath distroyed my herte
Nowe sey they thus whan wauter is goon
Than shal the blode of Ianycle succede
